text: This is a really nice tool. I don't even own a hair dryer, because I have so much hair it takes ages for me to dry all the spots and afterwards it looks much worse than if I let them dry on their own. I knew blowing my hair while brushing with a big brush would give amazing results, but honestly it's too heavy of a workout for a clumsy person like me - it would be difficult, tiring and then leave me all sweaty. It's just not something I can commit to, especially when stressing before going out. That's why I was excited to hear about one device that would kind of do both! And it was getting such great reviews. Mind that for the good review rates, the price is much lower than similar products from fancy brands like ghd or dyson.The brush is great and I am quite happy with my purchase. It gives me the same result as getting my hair blown with a thorough brush work at a hairdresser, which is amazing. It is very easy to operate and doesn't let you burn yourself no matter how clumsy you are. Many reviewers here and on YT say that you should not start right after washing your hair, but when it's almost dry, as it takes so long. Well my hair takes extremely long to dry but this device definitely handles it much quicker, for me waiting isn't really necessary, as long as I dry my hair with a towel first (try paper towels for even better results). I only wish it was a bit lighter, it does require some effort to keep it in the air, which I heard isn't an issue with expensive models like dyson. Still, I just don't think that makes them worth the price difference.

text: This is an honest review.I have a mid-lenght medium thick hair which is wavy when dried naturally. I'm very impressed so far. It took me about 15 minutes to do my hair and I would recommend using a normal hair dryer (or leaving the hair dry naturally) first little bit longer so it's only little bit moist (almost dry). It would definitely shorter the drying time. I mostly used the lower heat, the high heat sounds like an airplane taking off :)It glides through hair quite nicely, I didn't even have to brush it. It goes all the way to the roots lifting them so it makes it very full and bouncy. I also own an automatically rotating brush but I didn't mind at all rotating it myself, at least you can control it better. I love everything anout this, there is only one downside - it is quite heavy and when you have your hands in the air most of the time, I had to take a rest couple of times. But it feels sturdy and I hope it will last long.When I came back from the bathroom, my boyfriend said I look like I just came back from a hairdresser. text: I can't give it 5 stars. I had bought this item in hopes that it would replace my hair dryer and straightener, while cutting down on the time I spent doing my hair.I will admit, it has replaced both tools, but I definitely don't feel that I spend less time on my hair. If anything, I spend more time - maybe because I use the medium setting instead of high, as the high setting dries out my hair and makes it frizzy. My drying time has gone from 20mins (result: very dry hair) to 30-40mins (result: nicely styled hair).I did my research before buying this product because I wanted to make sure I bought the right product for my long, VERY thick hair.... and it seemed like this was the best choice, which it might be (maybe theres no perfect tool for the amount of hair I have). Shining of the hair after application is very good but for a saloon blow out you need to spend some time on your hair like 25-30 minutes for a mid length 75% dried hair. The brush is still quite big, very good for mid to long hair (no idea for short hair). Good to have the heat adjustment in the order of â€œ0-cool-1-2-3â€ cooling before turning off the machine is useful. The machine is not heavy but big, not very convenient for backpack traveling, still detachable brush is well thought. When compared to the rotating alternatives I liked this one more as there is no need for a speed control. When compared to 1000 watts alternatives the heat and strength of the hair flow is very sufficient in REVLON one-step plus. The only thing I wish there was a second brush is provided or other REVLON attachments are purchased additionally.

text: Just in the last two years alone, I have bought and returned 8 hairdryers including the Dyson dryer! Iâ€™ve also tried T3 Featherweight, a CHI dryer, BaByliss Pro Ferrari Volare, one that was 2000 watts and many more. Before purchasing this Revlon dryer my go to was called Inferno. Iâ€™ve also purchased every hair gadget ever invented!Scroll way to the bottom to see my updates!!!In my never-ending quest to reduce drying time with a bonus being able to eliminate my flat iron (which I honestly thought would never happen as I'm no newbie to hair products), I researched and purchase Revlonâ€™s One Step Hair Dryer. Holy Smokes!!! I love it!Here's my review after one week of using.Why itâ€™s so great:- I can go from sopping wet to fully styled, with no flat iron in 12 minutes! (was 30 before)- Powerful wind (shockingly), so it dries your hair while you style it- Has 3 settings, cool, low and high (and the settings are at the bottom of the handle so you wonâ€™t accidentally change or turn it off-and the high is great, not scalding hot like some dryers)- Oval brush, this is the INGENIOUS part of this design!!! The brush also has shorter bristles that grab your hair and works JUST LIKE having your hair blown out at the salon (I showed my friend who is a stylist and said this product would put him out of business if his clients knew about it). It grips and puts tension while drying so yes, it's about the size of a paddle brush with oval sides, and curling is likely not an option.- Grabs even shorter hairs. Many reviews said it wasn't good for shorter hair so I was surprised with my results. The back of my hair is just above the nape of my neck, so the shortest hairs could be maybe 2â€ long AND, I'm using it on my bangs!- I donâ€™t have to use a flat iron any more and I look like I walked out of the salon- On the days when I donâ€™t wash my hair, I've been use a spray bottle to mist my hair, and take a quick 3-5 minutes with the dryer and again, salon like quality, no flat iron, not even on my bangs! (see picture attached)- Lightweight, but a word of caution, the handle is a bit bulky. If you have tiny hands or problems with your hands it could be an issue- Adds volume! Iâ€™m not using any volume product before or after styling. As someone with thick hair you would think volume wouldnâ€™t be an issue, however thick hair is also heavy hair.Iâ€™m hoping to see a huge improvement in the health of my hair and reduction of split ends as a result of this dryer and no flat iron over the next few months.More About My Hair (should it be of interest)I have thick hair, not curly, not straight. Shoulder length in the front shorter in the back (like pretty short and barely pony tail possible), Lob style. If I didnâ€™t style my hair in the morning or after blow drying, it would be a mess. (like what your hair probably looked like when you were 8 years old and just got out of bed kind of hair.) I even have a pretty cool contraption that suction-cups to my mirror, holding my traditional hair dryer so I could dry using both hands.  I could never leave my hair wet or even damp, because it would never dry. I can't go to bed with wet hair as it's still really wet in the morning. Again, thick hair.It would take on average 15-20 minutes to just dry my hair. (at the salon, the stylist books an extra 15 minutes for me) Then a flat iron or curling iron because my motto before this dryer was â€˜if you want good hair you need hot tools and thatâ€™s the price you pay for good hair." And I was willing to pay the price!Needless to say, I had to carve out time to wash my hair. It was a big production, so to the flat iron I would go in between washes, with massive split ends being created every day.I've attached a selfie taken just this morning of my 2nd day hair. I used a spray bottle this morning, misted and dried. That volume - yeah, that was NEVER there with a flat iron!March 7, 2019 Update: Still loving this hair dryer!!! Everything I said above still stands and my hair is much healthier. I have recommended this to many friends and family and they have also found the same to be true. I always have a backup one in box just in case as I can't be without it! In the past year I have bought 4 back ups because each time I talk with a friend/family member about this dryer, they want one right away so I sell them mine then buy a new back up for myself LOL! The second picture I posted is my hair almost one year later, March 7, 2019 and I'm due for my cut in 2 days.IMPORTANT TIPS: I neglected to mention that if you'd like to prolong the life of your hairdrier see if you can find a way to hang it. Because it's a hairbrush essentially  laying it on its side (on the bristles) with the added weight of the dryer I'd recommend hanging this. What I do is fold up the cord in about 6" lengths, wrap a secure tie or clamp around it and hang it by a loop in the cord in my closet on a hook I use for belts. Also, every once in a while you should also clean or make sure they air flow screen near the bottom of the handle is free of dust, lint, etc. You know, the stuff that blocks your hairdryer and clothes dryer. Keeping this clean (for both LOL) allows your appliance to work more efficiently.August 12, 2020 - another update! If you're wondering if I still love this product... I DO! I've posted another picture, so now there's 2018, 2019 and 2020. Earlier this year I bought the Dyson Airwrap which I absolutely love for curls (it's worth it for the curls alone), straight up drying, or pre-drying, for that it's outstanding. At first I thought, ok, I'm not going to need my Revlon One-Step anymore (after having declared my love publicly for it) and tried for 3 months using the Dyson exclusively with round brush attachment, the flat brush and even bought the smaller flat brush attachments, and you know what?! When I do my straight hair style, I'm still using the REVLON! The reason the Revlon for creating straight hair outshines the Dyson, is because of their brush design, and the second layer of bristles. It grabs the hair AND creates tension. Without the tension there's no way to remove those bumps and kinks that my hair wants to create. So, this is still on the top of my list!July 2022 update... still loving this hair dryer! Recently I ran into someone who recognized me from my review here (who did buy a One STEP and loves it!), and reminded me it was time to update this review. I still use my Dyson dryer/air wrap for days when I'm not doing a super straight finish but instead with curls, however the Revlon One Step is still awesome for ultra smooth hair hands down! The grip of the brush is what truly makes it better than Dyson's brush alternative. The last picture posted is me now in 2022 after just using my Revlon One Step.

title: After years of trying and searching for an AMAZING hairdryerâ€¦ finally!

text: I really like using this product, I bought the size for mid-short hair and my hair is just past my shoulders but quite thick.The package is nice and there didn't seem to be unnecessary packaging which I sometimes find with other products.It is bigger than I expected so I'm glad I got the smaller size. It also takes some getting used to with how to hold the brush and the right amount of hair to use - the smaller sections you use, the quicker your hair dries overall I would say as you're not having to repeatedly go over it. I do find it takes more time overall than a normal hair dryer, but it gives you a nicer finish.The bristles aren't too hard and there are two settings, plus a 'cool' setting. The heat can get a bit much if you're not moving the brush quick enough or if the hot air is directly against your skin, and there's no option to hold a cool button to cool the air. Instead, you would have to change the whole setting to cool, which I find difficult whilst I'm using the brush.Using the brush gives you a blow-dry appearance with lots of volume. I find that I don't have to straighten my hair after this at all, whereas I would if I had used a normal hair dryer.Overall, would recommend and think it's worth the money!

title: Itâ€™s really good

text: This is good for those who normally dry their hair with a larger brush. It's a much easier process than holding the drying AND a hair brush.This unit is LARGE. It wasn't too much of a problem for me, but if you have smaller hands, and/or little upper arm strength, this might be an issue for you. The unit itself is 13" long.  (See my photo showing the dryer beside a regular sized brush.) The cord length is 6 feet which was plenty long for me, and it swivels at the base which is great for preventing the cord from tangling up.Essentially this is just a huge oval brush that blows air from within the brush. The air intake inlets are at the bottom of the handle. A neat concept and again may work well for you depending on how you normally dry your hair.It has 3 settings. (COOL, LOW, HIGH). I used it on LOW (low heat, low speed) which is the setting I normally use my hair dryer on. It did take a while to dry my hair that way. (I have long (well past shoulder length) fine hair. (Hair drying in general increases the frizziness unless I put a lot of smoothing product in it.)I dried the top part of my head by leaning over and the bristles actually felt really good against my scalp. (Normally I don't do this with when drying with a brush because it would just get tangled up in my hair. But it didn't seem to be a problem with this larger brush and it's "Tangle-free Combination Bristles".)Doing this also created more volume up top than I would normally get with a dryer.I'll be honest. I normally let my hair air dry, often overnight with my hair up in a loose bun on the top of my head so it doesn't get in the way of sleeping. It produces nice soft waves in the morning without any bed head. I feel this is much healthier for my hair than constantly blow-drying it. I also am easily able to go 5 days without washing my hair, and up to 7 days before it starts to look greasy. (It took a long time to work up to this but again my hair is much healthier because of it.) And don't panic, I shower more regularly. Lol! I just don't wash my hair every time I shower.Regardless this dryer is great for the occasions when I do intend to dry and then straighten my hair with a flat iron.Also I'll mention that hair build-up around the brush head will likely decrease the flow of air and potentially harm the unit over time. I made a point of running the pointy end of a comb through the bristles so I could easily pull the hair out when I was done.The unit seems well made and durable, but maybe priced a little on the high side at $62.99. The packaging is top notch. (Embossing, metallic gold ink, matte varnish, gloss varnish, & spot colours. <- I work in the graphics arts industry.) Without a doubt no expense was spared on the packaging, which also contributes to its cost. Not sure that ALL of those details were required for it to stand out on store shelves but obviously somebody does. For me personally I would prefer a cheaper product price in simple but clean looking packaging since it's going to be thrown out anyway. The Revlon brand has been around for a long time and is synonymous with quality. (My last Revlon hair dryer is over 15 years old, and is still going strong.) I think their products will sell just fine without over the top packaging. And when companies start doing any small thing they can to reduce waste and costs - THEN I'm impressed.Regardless, my review & rating is based on the product itself.
date: Kundenrezension aus Kanada ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ amÂ 18. Dezember 2016
title: Good for those who normally dry their hair using a large round brush, like your hairdresser does.

It has made my hair care routine so much more simple.Once I exit the shower, I let my hair towel dry for about 5 mins then I use a wet brush ti distribute my leave in conditioner, then air dry for maybe another 5. When it starts feeling warm, move to the next section.It looks silly if you leave it because it will be standing up, but once cooled you can gently brush it (I use a wet brush) and it will just give a bit of volume but it will smooth out your locks.For the back, since it has a bit more length, I do actually brush the dryer through with no issues. text: So glad I bought mine while it was on an offer. I have shoulder length fine/medium wavy hair with a fringe. My hair is normally flat and frizzy.  I have always used hot air brushes and especially for my flat fringe. I had the original revlon round brush long ago. Very good quality and for me this one didn't blow to hot on the highest setting. All my brushes have been used on the lower setting. Maybe I didn't use it long enough...Mmmm. My hair was half dry already, and finished it of in 10min. Was fairly big so the bigger brush must be huge. Probably still to big but it did the job on drying and giving my hair body and shape. Gave me a nice sort of bob, smooth hair with minimal frizz. Felt nice.  Not great on my fringe sadly, just to big to get under a small bit of hair and I normally do a sort of ringlet around my cheeks and this didn't work for me also. More wavy than rings. Would be better suited for long hair that is full of body and wavy. It is pretty chunky to hold but I will get the hang of it. I have this brush for my head hair for the body and waves and have bought the revlon round 38mm for my fringe and any round curls.  I also bought the zip up case to contain the brush which is brilliant for storage, hope my other brush fits in it! All in all I love revlon, good brush and would buy it again.

text: I have medium length bleached 2B curly hair with a lot of frizz. I bought this as I cannot get on with using a round brush and a hairdryer, and I wanted smooth hair with root volume.First off: it is excellent at drying hair very quickly. I use on the lowest speed once my hair is 70 / 80% dry and section my hair into rough thirds. The size of the barrel is more than enough  for my hair - I'd say any bigger and I'd find it hard to handle.The hair doesn't get caught when pulling the brush through it and it is demonstrably smoother when I'm done. I cant say too much about root volume as I haven't done a thorough test of that yet, but I imagine with a little bit more patience you can get a decent lift.It isn't going to give you curls, the barrel is too big for that (even though this is the smaller version), but you can get a bit of movement in it. Overall it's perfect for what I need, getting rid of frizz after washing so my hair is smooth and easier to manage for the next few days!

text: I stumbled across this product over a year ago while on Amazon and saw tons of reviews. I actually appreciate reading other people's reviews, but I very rarely post them myself. I feel a bit guilty about this, so today I am writing a bunch of reviews for things I've bought over the past year and a bit.I love this thing. It is really light and easy to use. I have long curly hair that will easily go very curly or frizzy, but it is not a super strong or coarse curl. My hair feels somewhat fine although it doesn't read that way officially when it is curly because it can be so big.I find it really easy to straighten with this dryer. To be honest, I don't like spending much time on my hair, and I would not bother with straightening with a regular dryer. I don't know how other women can stand spending much time on that. This dryer makes it really easy, and so I do style my hair more straight quite often now. I let my hair dry a little bit in the air or towel first, so I'm not putting so much heat directly on it. It's really easy to use, and my arms don't get tired. I can dry my hair to my liking pretty quickly. I don't like my hair to lie completely flat, and it's easy to control how much I try and straighten with this thing. I tend to stop before my hair is completely dry, and put a bit of putty or leave-in conditioner, so that while far straighter than usual, it still has some interesting curves and body. I find it fairly easy to clean hair out of the bristles. If you use high heat, you should be careful of your fingers when holding the edge with the hand not on the handle.I think my only suggestion to the manufacturer for improvement would be to put a little loop on it, so I can hang it up like I do with my regular hair dryer. I have to just stuff it into the cabinet under the sink, when I would rather hang it up.I am really glad I got this, and also thankful to the other women who took time to write reviews that helped me make my decision. As I said, I don't usually bother with reviews, and this purchase is old enough that probably there are other awesome products on the market. But I'm happy with this.
date: Kundenrezension aus Kanada ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ amÂ 6. Februar 2021

text: The product was well made and much bigger than I thought.  In fact, it may be big for most women because the handle is quite wide in circumference.It makes a lot of noise. like a small vacuum cleaner.  It has enough settings for most purposes.The thing that I am not satisfied with is the fact that the air pushed is not directable; it goes everywhere.  If you have it against your hair, most of the air will flow out the holes that are on the other side of the tip because it goes towards the path of least resistance.  This causes most of the air to be wasted because it is not being used to dry your hair.I have other hair dryers from Tescom that are smaller than this and their tips are removable so that if the teeth break off I can buy another tip.  The motor on these is phenomenal because they are used every day and have lasted over 10 years.  The motor mechanism on the Revlon is similar and they are pretty noisy.  The tips on the Tescom units have air holes on one side so all the air is directed through these holes to a small area - none of the air is wasted.Further, the Tescoms seem to push more air than the Revlon.  This could be due to the air going everywhere on the Revlon so the pressure of the flow is weaker in any given direction.  To me this is a serious flaw in the design.  The only useful condition for this would be if you had a lot of long hair and you wrap it around the tip so that the air is hitting your hair all around it.  For shorter hair, I do not find it very useful.On a good note, the teeth/bristles of the Revlon are soft and feel good on my scalp.  They are variable lengths so that they will catch short and long hair.All in all, for the same or lower price, I would recommend getting a Tescom hair dryer rather than this one.  I saw some Panasonic ones that look like the Tescoms here in Amazon, but the Tescoms that I got were from Japan and I have not been able to find them locally.I hope this helps someone out there.

text: Let me start with the results before getting into my mini essay of a review. I go from 4c super short kinky hair to almost bone straight bra strap length hair in under 30 minutes. To get anything close to this blow out texture I used to have to blow dry with a denman brush afterwards flat ironing. The latter process took HOURS, sometimes a whole day and it was PAINFUL.I bought this product approximately on November 30th 2020 today is December 23, 2020. Happy Holidays! I have since used this product 4 times. Once on a pre blowdried hair to quickly get my bangs straight in an emergency (haha), once on fully drenched hair, twice on semi dry hair. This is coming from a woman who previously blow dried her hair once a year because the process was too much time, pain, and effort in comparison to air drying via twists or braids. If you have kinky hair you know the struggle.Some reviewers have claimed damage. Therefore I wanted to wait until using this product a decent amount of time before posting my review (after the first use I cried and wanted to immediately proclaim my love as a review). I have experienced zero breakage. In fact my denman brush + normal blow drier combo caused more "shedding" in comparison. I haven't experienced an increase in split ends (I will update later if I do). When I wet my hair it goes back to its very short kinky texture. It has loosened and defined my curls a bit when prepooing but once fully drenched after washing my hair goes back to the 4c, shrunken to my scalp from bra length, unperceivable curl pattern we all know and love.The only problem I see occurring is finding a way to clean the bristles as build up from leave in conditioner and heat protectant will occur. But since the bristles are connected to something electric normal forms of brush cleaning would obviously lead to short circuiting. I'm just planning on crossing that bridge whenever I get there.TLDR: Get it, you will not regret it. <3
date: Kundenrezension aus Kanada ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦ amÂ 23. Dezember 2020
title: Review from a 4c textured user. Get it, just get it!

text: First of all, I am a very impatient person and dislike the time it takes to blow dry my hair.  So I was recommended this device by my hairdresser as she knows me and my hair inside and out.  I'm still on the fence if it is quicker than the standard round brush and blow dryer but it does smooth out my hair better than the blow dryer and brush.  However, I wonder if I just bought a bore brush instead of this device would that have solved my frizz problem with the blow dryer.  I do find the device is large and awkward sometimes when maneuvering around...I find that the fact I'm right handed makes my left side always look better than my right side.  It often curls badly on the right side because of the shape of the device and the fact I'm not left handed.  The curls are horrible, ugly ass curls always going the wrong way and have odd shapes to them.  I then need my hair straightener to fix it.  The temperature on the device runs a little hotter than I'd like, even on the low or cool setting.  I have been wondering if the Dyson set would have been the better choice.  My hair tends to frizz more with hotter devices.  I let my hair air dry for an hour and I still need another 20-30 minutes with the device.  My hair is extremely thick and retains a lot of water after the shower.  Even after towel drying.  The quest for the perfect device is still upon me, but this one seems to be okay for the price point, so we will see if practice makes perfect or if my lack of opposite hand coordination will leave me throwing the device out the window in frustration...time will tell ;)

They used technology developed by boars!!! These creatures have advanced by leaps and bounds. text: Okay so I was super skeptical about this product.. Mostly because I have zero abilities to do my hair & the price (was a little less than 70$). I was very intimidated at first because it's a lot bigger than I thought it would be & I wasn't really sure what to do with it. But let me tell you.. THIS THING WORKS. My hair is rather long (under my breasts) & frizzy. Normally when I blow dry my hair it frizzes beyond belief and then I have to straighten it back down. With this, all I did was wait until my hair was about 80% dry, then separated it into three sections & passed the brush through multiple times (like combing your hair). This whole process took me about 10-15 mins and I did it while my show was on commercials. This is WAY LESS TIME than blow drying which normally takes me a good 30 mins. The final product is smooth and very soft & doesn't have that dry feel my blow drier would give me. I still have to go over it once with the hair straightener tomorrow morning but I am SO VERY PLEASED WITH THIS PRODUCT. I would buy it again and recommend to my friends. I'm estimating that using this probably took me around 10-15 mins plus maybe another 10 mins tomorrow to pass a hair straightener before I leave the house. I always dreaded drying/straightening my hair because it would take almost an hour. Now I can keep my hair long and shave off about 30 mins off the whole process. This is a GAME CHANGER. I say spend the money, you won't regret it. If I can use it & my greatest hair accomplishment is straightening without missing any sections, you can use this too :)Downsides: It doesn't have a hook or loop to hang somewhere, So I'll have to find a basket or something to let it rest without it being on the bristles. It is rather big so it takes some getting used to in terms of holding & manipulating it.

text: SO. I have used this styling product twice and have a few things to say about it. First of all, yes it is a great product so those 4/5 star reviews you're seeing are mostly true. What drew me to buy this product in the first place is the ease of use. For someone like myself who doesn't ever do anything "fancy" and wears their un-styled hair down 363 days a year this product is a godsend. However, if you know what you're doing and are just looking to shave a few minutes off your routine, you will be very disappointed. First off, it does give you somewhat of a blow-dry look but don't expect it to turn out as nice as with a round brush and hairdryer. Because the brush head is so large, you can't get it close to the roots to get that volume. Your mileage may vary but for me, I held it at the roots for a bit as they instruct on the box, used the cool setting to set it AND hairspray and 10 minutes later the top part was completely flat. This is where I think the smaller brush head would win. Secondly, it gets VERY hot ... almost as hot as a flat iron. Maybe I got a lemon and so the temperature doesn't regulate correctly but with mine, I'm afraid of actually holding it close to my head for fear of getting burned. And the cool setting doesn't get cool at all but is more slightly warm. In the next iteration of this product, I would like to see it come with a little built-in loop so that you can hang it on a hook as well as a cord tie.

I was going to get a more expensive/better quality dryer brush combo to try first as I figured the quality of a more expensive item would serve me better but I decided to try the Revlon dryer brush to see if I liked the concept. text: I'm quite impressed.  I used the one step hair dryer today (literally waited for a few hours with damp hair for the package to be delivered lol)  and I'm happy with the results.As you can see I have very long hair and medium thickness (natural wave when not staightened).  It took me about 20 minutes to get my hair like this.  I didn't use my blow dry spray b/c I wanted to see how powerful the dryer actually is.  My hair was only damp, as I mentioned, I was in a towel for a few hours while I was waiting on the delivery.  With that said, I'm still impress.  Towel dried hair with my normal dryer and blow dry spray takes about 30-40 minutes then I have to use a flat iron.This blow dryer does get hot. A thermal protectant is a must.  The cool blast doesn't get cool in my opinion.  The cool blast you also have to flick the switch, it doesn't have a button like most blow dryers do.  That is the only negative I would say. That is why I removed a star.As for the weight of the dryer. I found it slightly lighter than my blow dryer. However since the brush is built in I found it so much easier to use then a standard hair dryer and and round brush.Size wise its bigger than I had expected, but in my case I prefer it as the brush is bigger and great for my long hair.All in all I'm very happy with this product.

text: I am the 100% original skeptic when it comes to new products like this.But this?  This is the real deal.  I have shoulder length, fine curly hair, and blowing it dry straight is generally a winter thing for me.  Basically, by the time I'm fully dry, I've started to sweat so badly from being under the dryer that I'm frizzing up again.I had very little hope for this...not even sure why I bothered.  I can't say how glad I am that I did.The time it took to dry my hair was cut by about 40%.  And these best part?  I haven't touched my ceramic iron since I bought it.  I can literally acheive the smooth finish I like WITHOUT the added step of the iron.  (Which honestly, fries my thin hair, and I try to use sparingly.)  The amount of volume I can get is awesome too.  I don't need Texas sky-high hair, but I like a bit of volume, especially now that my hair is thinning out a little bit.  (Welcome to getting older ladies.)  Also, I see a lot of people saying that it's heavy.  Yes, it it a bit heavier than the average hari dryer, but the control you have while not having to mess with two items it worth it.  And if I'm not holding it as long......no biggie.My ONLY complaint is basically the same one that some other users have had.  I don't like the positioning of the temperature controls.  I like to be able to dry an area and then hit it with a blast of cool air to "lock" the style.  This isn't easily achieved with the button being on the bottom of the handle.  But no worries!  Not a game changer.If you're on the fence about this.....give it a try.  Worst case scenario - you can return it, but I doubt you will.

text: I have medium thickness, frizzy, wavy hair. Usually after blow drying it using a hair dryer on medium heat (my hair would be very frizzy and wavy at this point), I would have to take my straightener in the highest heat setting and slowly flat iron it. Sometimes, the top layers of my hair would need 2-3 rounds of straightening to get it straight. This process would take about 30 minutes start to finish.Then I used this styler. I was skeptical at first, especially for the top layers of my hair, but it did the job with one step! I use this dryer when my hair is 50% air dried. text: My hair looks nice and shiny. Nicely curled ends which look like a blow out. I cannot for the life of me do a blow out with a separate brush and dryer, especially near the rear of my head, so this 2-in-1 product is amazing for that. I do have a few complaints, however.There are 2 settings with heat: low and high. The low setting is a little bit too low since it takes a while to dry. The hot setting is way to hot and I think many people will burn themselves trying to use it or burn their hair. I always use the low setting, but typically let my hair air-dry 80% first or do a quick blow dry to lightly damp with a regular blow dryer. The machine is also really loud on the high setting... like I want to wear ear plugs loud.I also think they could have made the brush a little less "catchy" on the hair. I need to be careful how I twist it so my hair doesn't get stuck. I lose a decent amount of hair on the brush when I am done. Maybe it is just my hair texture (lots of fine hair that falls out easily), but I think a smoother brush would have worked better for me.Overall a great product that fills a distinct need, but there is room for improvement before I love this.

text: I would actually like to give this product 3.5 stars but it's not possible. I'm sure it would be a 5 star product for people with less frizzy and difficult hair. However, the product is made really well and it's very easy to use, although the large handle takes just a bit of getting used to. The brush does not tangle in my fine, frizzy, and curly hair. I like to use it on days when I'm just too lazy or tired to pull out the round brush and the blow drier, but I this doesn't give me results as good as a blow dryer and round brush.Although it's easy to use, my results aren't as good as I was hoping. This dryer will smooth out my curls but I am still left with quite a bit of frizz which needs some touching up with a curling iron or flat iron.The drier doesn't blow very forceful air, which is good because if it was more powerful, it would tangle our hair and cause more frizz. The only downfall is that it takes longer to dry, especially at the roots.You can use the brush to curl under or smooth over the hair. i got back and forth between the two motions.I think anyone with wavy hair or hair that is not as damaged and frizzy as mine would have excellent results. Unfortunately for me, my hair is super frizzy and damaged.

text: I previously purchased the knock-off of the Revlon one-step when the Revlon version wasn't in stock. The knock-off version worked really well for the first month but then it started shutting off on its own during use. I replaced it with another knock-off, which worked but after a couple of months I noticed blue sparks inside the barrel when I was using it - probably not the safest thing to have around a head of wet hair! I decided to get the real deal Revlon one when it was back in stock and I am not disappointed. Right away I could feel that it was better constructed, the chord does not get tangled the way the knock-offs did, so I no longer had to unplug it to untangle the chord during use. It also dries my hair faster than the knock-off did. Hands down, knock-off or not, the one-step dryer is the best device I have ever used for my hair - I go from wet, thick, curly hair to straight and dry in a quarter of the time. My advice though, if the Revlon one is in stock - pay the extra $30 and get it. You will feel safer knowing it meets safety standards, and it works just that much better than the knock-off!

text: I got the genuine Revlon dryer, not the chinese knockoff noted in other reviews. I'll start with the cons - It's much bigger than expected, which makes drying closer to the roots basically impossible. Unless you just use it like a normal brush, instead of drying from under, which makes your hair a bit flat. The low setting doesnt dry my hair, but the high setting is so hot I'm worried itll melt my hair. So hot, hotter than any hair dryer I've ever used. Hot enough it's hard to use to dry all of my (very thin) hair at once. There is no temp option, just low or high or cool. It's much heavier than expected and awkward to use. I dont think I'd take it travelling (one of my review options here) because it only works in North America (clearly stated in ad, and I knew) and it is just too big and heavy to carry around for a trip. Not to mention it would definitely set off a fire alarm in a hotel room for blasting out so much super hot air so quickly. With that said, it makes my hair look pretty smooth and cuts out the need for a dryer and straightener. I just wish it was a bit more convenient to use.

text: This was a gift to a family member as they were talking about this particular model in the store but the store wanted crazy amounts of money for this hair dryer so i found this SAME model on Amazon for cheaper. I thought i was paying for a genuine Revlon Hair Dryer & Volumizer. I didn't even know this at the time to purchasing the product as i gave to them for a gift. About three weeks later they opened the box to find a 220V plug which i found very weird. I did some research and found by other reviews on Amazon that others were experiencing the same issue. I went to the store and decided to own up to purchasing "The name brand" and found a standard 120V outlet plug on the end. I compared the two, which i am having trouble uploading the pictures but both of the handles are almost different but box is the exact same and leads to be believe that this is the same product so in the end this is the Knock OFF product which is why it's cheaper. I am disappointed because i now am past the return window so what i might end up doing it when the dryer goes i will swap the cords to this one and hopefully it works but it's seems that some reviews are positive and negative which means some possibly have received the real product. At the end if has a Pink Bottom = 220V, if has a Black bottom = 110V.
